dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High noon. A handsome, well-loved, well-used car is broken down on t side of the interstate, just outside of downtown Dallas. A woman named JEWEL, late 50s / early 60s, stands beside KICKING IT in frustration. She’s got a loose blouse on, a worn jeans, and about a billion bangles on her right wris She touches the hood, but it’s a little too hot. A second and she gets it open and is met with a cloud of white ste She looks around, somewhat helplessly. There aren’t that cars on the road. Those that are out zoom pass without seeming to notice her. But one car passes and SWERVES over to the shoulder about fifty feet in front of her. It’s an old CHEVY CUTLASS. The door opens, and a man gets out. His name is FORREST TUCKER. He’s wearing a BLUE SUIT and he gets out of the car he puts a matching hat atop his he He looks quite striking and dapper, there on the side of road. He walks towards her. She watches him, a bit suspicious a first. When he’s close enough, he shouts...

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Need some help?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Maybe. They both look at the steam coming from under the hood. Clearly bit more than a maybe situation.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Lemme take a look... She gives him an ‘all yours’ gesture. He walks up to the engine and peers in, waving away the vapors.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: ...damn thing just started choking up about a mile back. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (4/4/17)

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was gonna try to make it to the next exit but... He looks for a long time. Long enough for a burst of radi steam to escape the engine. Jewel finally asks:

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what, you think it’s the radiator?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Is it shot?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Do you know anything about cars?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Eh, not really. Another belch of steam as we cut to... INT./EXT. FORREST’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER They’re driving now, in Forrest’s car. Jewel sits in the passenger seat. Forrest keeps stealing glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Where were you headed?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Nowhere, really.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Just driving.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Just driving. She glances into his back seat. Sees a briefcase there, inconspicuously tucked into the corner.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: That was a nice truck.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, you think so?  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 3.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Me too. (beat) I stole it.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Did you? She lets him hang a beat before...

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: No. It was my husband's car.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Ah. (beat) Where’s he at?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Well. He's dead, so...that’s where he’s at.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Gotcha. Another long beat. An unexpectedly comfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask your name?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Jewel.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Your name’s Jewel?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: That's really your name? Jewel?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You don’t believe me?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No, I believe you. It just suits you is all.  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 4.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What about you - what's your name? Handsome-In-A-Blue-Suit?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: (laughing) My name’s Bob. Bob Callahan.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: And where are you headed, Bob Callahan?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Home. I’ve been on the road for a while.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I’m in sales.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Selling what?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Oh, this and that. What’re you looking for? He shoots her a killer grin that stops the line of questioning dead. She notices that he’s wearing HEARING AIDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH THE PLATE GLASS WINDOW OF A SERVICE STATION: Forr pulls right up to the front door. He and Jewel walk insid and Forrest rings a bell at the counter. He rings it a bu of times. A guy in a mechanic’s coveralls, hands covered in grease calls from the back.

dialogues.speaker: MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I can hear you. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: This young lady needs a tow truck.  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 5. He keeps RINGING THAT BELL, repeatedly, playfully, like a little kid annoying their parent. Jewel can’t help but bl CAMERA ZOOMS IN on her face as that bell goes DING DING D

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they’re seated at a little restaurant nearby, waiting her car to get towed. Cups of coffee between them and mos finished slices of pumpkin pie. Awkward silence. Broken by...

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: You like horses.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What? He points to a pin on her blouse. A little silver horse.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: So - you're a cowgirl and you like to steal cars. What else am I missing? She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: That's pretty much it. I've got three horses -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Three horses.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: - and I ride every day, and -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What are their names?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: The horses?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Wiley, Clementine and Dorothy Jean.  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 6.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Dorothy Jean. Dorothy Jean sounds like my kinda gal.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Do you ride?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Me? No. I never have. It’s on my list.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What list is that?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: The list of things I wanna do.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Well, you better hurry up.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: How come? Beat. She shrugs off that question. The waitress comes wi the check.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: All right then. Whenever you're ready. She leaves the check in its little folder on the table. J reaches for it but Forrest grabs it first.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: No, you - come on, you gave me a lift, it’s the last I can do -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Please. I insist. A beat, and then Forrest slides the check back to her.  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 7.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Thank you. Forrest watches as she peels a few single bills from a th clip of them in her purse. She lays them on the check. A beat passes, just long enough for Jewel to have to reac slightly to find her way back into the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: So what did you say you do? Sales?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: ..-Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Like door to door, or...

dialogues.speaker: FORREST JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++No, no. .+-bible salesman?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Definitely not.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Can I be honest with you? I don’t know the first thing about sales.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: oh.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I made that up.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: So...what do you do then?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: It’s a secret.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Oh is it now?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: And why is that?  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 8.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Because if I told you, you might not want to see me again.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Who said I was going to see you again?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Would you? She hesitates for a moment - sizing Forrest up once more - and then grabs the bill the waitress left, tears off a piece of it, takes a pen out from her purse and writes something down. A PHONE NUMBER. She slides it back to him His eyes dart from the paper to her and then back again. Then he tears off a larger piece of paper off the same bi He reaches across the table and takes her pen, and then quickly, deliberately writes something down on that piece paper. We don’t see what he writes. He slides it across the table to her. She takes it, looks at it, puts on her reading glasses an then bursts out laughing. She looks back to him.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: This isn’t...you aren’t serious are you? He shrugs, like it’s no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Why would you even tell me then?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I trust you.  Pink Rev. (3/24/17) 9.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You just met me.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Sometimes you just know.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: With me. You know.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Well, you're still sitting here.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Because I don’t believe you. And if I did believe you

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What would be worse? If I was lying about this, or telling the truth? Long beat, and then...

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Prove it.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: You want me to prove it?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What‘1l you do if I can?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I won't walk out on you. Forrest looks around.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Beat.  Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 10.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna do that.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: See. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Not because I can’t. It just isn’t my style.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Not your style.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You've got a style.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Tell me what that is then.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Well, first of all - this place. This place isn’t my style. But say this were a bank. You've got that counter up there, the girl behind it. You find a good spot, like the one we've got here, and you wait. You wait and you watch and you get into the swing of things and when the time feels right - maybe it’s a couple hours, maybe it’s a couple days but when it feels right you make your move. You stroll right in. Easiest thing in the world. There’s the girl. You walk right up and look her in the eye and say ma’am, this is a robbery. I’ve got a gun. You show it, like this. You say: take a bag and fill it up. I’m keeping my eye on you. Don’t try anything funny. I like you. I like you a whole lot. I might just be falling for you. Don’t go breaking my heart now. (beat) And she'd fill up a bag with money, and she'd give it to me, and you’d go out the way you came in and she'd...  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 1. He looks at Jewel.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, you tell me what she'd do. HOLD ON Jewel, who doesn’t realize she was holding her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest Tucker awakens. He’s laying on a bunk, alone in a prison cell. It is

dialogues.speaker: TWO YEARS EARLIER
dialogues.text: He looks at the barred door of his cell. Today's gonna be the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest walks down the hall, down the long corridor of ce Following all the other prisoners. The usual morning routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest drinks his coffee. Another prisoner sits down * opposite him.: TEDDY GREEN, tall, lanky, with silver hair receding on his head. *

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: How you feeling today? *

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Good as ever. *

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Got something for you. * He slides a little origami boat across the table. *  10 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Quentin: a square fortress of a prison, positioned on very edge of the San Francisco Bay. Almost 100 years old Like a crumbling castle, on the verge of collapsing right into the icy waters of the Pacific. Forrest crosses the prison yard from one of the wings to PRISON WORKSHOP. He's walking with other prisoners, escor by a guard. He walks with a slight shuffle, his head hung little low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest stands at a heavy duty POWER DRILL in the prison - his place in the assembly line that’s putting together cheap furniture for institutional use. Raw lumber goes in end, chairs and tables come out the other. WALLER is working on another machine. TEDDY on yet anothe A PRISON TRUSTEE named JIM supervises the shop from the comfort of a recliner. He’s petting one of the many CATS run amongst the piles of lumber. A WHISTLE BLOWS. Forrest looks up again, glancing through sawdust at the clock hanging over the shop door. 12 PM. The other prisoners shut off their power tools, put down their hammers and saws. TRUSTEE JIM struggles to raise himself from his armchair. The cat in his lap isn’t keen getting up.

dialogues.speaker: TRUSTEE JIM
dialogues.text: (to cat) c'mon Downsers. Ooopsie-daisy. The split second he’s alone, Forrest’s demeanor changes. shoulders straighten. He lifts his head. He pulls the board off the table. He leaves the drill running, leaving its whine to fill the air as he walks to back of the shop and grabs something from behind a STACK WwooD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest walks through the prison yard, pushing a large RUBBISH BIN full of who knows what. He passes a guard who walking towards the mess hall.  Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 12a.

dialogues.speaker: HUNGRY GUARD
dialogues.text: Lunchtime, Tucker.  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 13.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I know. Jim just told us to throw this shit out.

dialogues.speaker: HUNGRY GUARD
dialogues.text: Better hurry up. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You think this thing’ll float?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Doesn't have to float. Just has to not sink. 1 INT. WAREHOUSE - CONTINUOUS 1. Warehouse scene. One shot. Magic.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17)

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES PAST the water...up to the words RUB-A-DUB- DUB.... Then up to Waller and Teddy, both of whom are rowing with makeshift oars... .+.and finally finding FORREST, pulling the sail open and grinning like a free man as the wind whips through his ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting now. CAMERA TRACKS across a Marin County beach. Wild and untam By and by we find that handmade boat, rocking gently in t surf, bleeding BLUE PAINT onto the sand. CAMERA PUSHES IN ...and finds the words RUB-A-DUB-DUB painted on the side.  24 25 26 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 17.

dialogues.speaker: AGAINST BLACK 25
dialogues.text: That sound of a POLICE RADIO crackles.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE DISPATCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Two-baker-four, that address again is twenty-three Dyer Street. Fifty- one-fifty male causing four fifteen inside the residence. Suspect sighted leaving on foot...

dialogues.speaker: POLICE RADIO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Roger that two bravo four, sending backup... INT. JOHN HUNT’S CAR - NIGHT 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find a detective, sound asleep in his car. His name is JOHN HUNT. He’s handsome, on the drop edge of forty, a little bit of salt peppering his sideburns. His head rests against the window. He looks very peaceful .+-until there’s a knock on the glass, and then the passe side door opens and his partner LT. KELLEY gets in with t cups of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Were you sleeping?  28 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 18.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Seriously were you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: No. I was just thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: You were fucking sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: I look like I’m sleeping when I'm thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: You tell that to Maureen?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: All the time.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Does she believe you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelley and Hunt investigate a crime scene - a robbery at donut shop. There is broken glass and SQUASHED DONUTS all over the floors. A mess of powdered sugar and jelly. Behi the counter the register has been torn open. Lt. Kelley talks to the owner, who looks mighty shaken up John Hunt doesn’t seem too interested.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: And that’s when he threw your wares and such down on the floor here?

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Yes, he just started knocking all the trays on the floor and causing a ruckus. His hands were shaking. That’s what I kept noticing, his hands were shaking all over the place and if he pulled the trigger - I mean, I don’t think he even could have pulled the trigger, he was so jacked up, but - aH Ae  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 18a.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: No, no. You did the right thing. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: How much was in the register?

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: Nothing, we weren’t even open yet.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: So he didn’t actually take anything?

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SHOP OWNER
dialogues.text: No, he just threw my product all over the floor.  27 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 19.

dialogues.speaker: DONUT SHOP OWNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you're gonna catch him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Ehhhhhh... INT. JOHN HUNT’S POLICE CAR - DAWN John Hunt drives in his car with Lt. Kelley. Police radio crackling as they go.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Do you know where you’re going? 27  29 30 31 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briefing room. The CAPTAIN is giving a talk to everyone. move from one face to the next...

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CALDER
dialogues.text: Some of you - you know who you are - you’re acting like a bunch of spoiled little kids. I don’t have time for that. Your partners don’t have time for that. If you don’t grow up, carry your weight, do your job, I’m gonna bump you down to bicycle detail. John Hunt listens in from the adjacent LOCKER ROOM, leani in just enough to get an earful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now John Hunt sits at his desk, buried behind a mountain paperwork. Lt. Kelly approaches with their secretary, MARTHA.

dialogues.speaker: LY. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Hey, ah...don’t want to make a big deal out of it or anything, but we all pitched in to get a little something for you. He sets a cupcake down in front of him with a single cand He lights it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: All downhill from here. John Hunt pinches the flame and takes the candle out and shoves the entire cupcake in his mouth. INT. LIVING ROOM - JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - MORNING 31 A lock clicks, a doorknob turns. John Hunt comes home. It raining outside. He sets his badge down on the table by the door. He can hear children’s voices in the kitchen.  Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 20a. Then A LITTLE BOY runs from the kitchen to the bedroom. H stops for a moment, sees John Hunt, looks at him like he’ been caught in the act, and then continues on into the kitchen. John Hunt sighs, and then heads to the kitchen. He makes around the corner...  32 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 21. INT. KITCHEN - JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 32 -..where that little boy, his son TYLER (7), and daughter ABILENE (10) are waiting for him along with his wife MAUR There’s a coffee cake on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Happy birthday! He turns around, sleepily feigning shock, and then back again.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Awwww.....what is this?

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: A surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: You should have told me.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: Then it wouldn't have been a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Thank you guys. Who put you up to this?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: It was their idea. He walks up behind Maureen and puts his arms around her a kisses the back of her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I tried to tell them. Dad’s gonna be cranky and he’s not gonna want want anyone to remind him how old he is...but they said they didn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: It’s your birthday. I’m not gonna say a damn thing. I gotta get to class. She turns around and touches his sideburns, finds the lit bit of gray there.

dialogues.speaker: AHHH HOF
dialogues.text: aH ae

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 21a. MAUREEN (CONT’D) This wasn’t there yesterday. cur TO: Abilene is reciting something she’s memorized for school. she speaks, Tyler looks up at his dad, who sits down at t table.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: That's a lie and you know it.  33 34 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 22. INT. JOHN HUNT’S POLICE CAR - MORNING 33 John Hunt's car is stopped at a railroad crossing. He and both kids are all in the front seat. It’s RAINING and Tyl knocks his galoshes together in time with the windshield wipers. Abilene is still reading aloud.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: You guys - you gotta be quiet for a second, okay? Just for a second. I got a headache and I’m tired and I ate too much cake and I’m just... The police radio squawks. And then squawks again. The sou of the railroad crossing clanging, the radio, the kids, t rain - it’s too much. Hunt grabs it and hands it to Abile

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Hold this button and say 10- 4. Abilene hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on, press the button and say...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: 10-4, Good Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: 10-4 Good Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I wanna do it...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Okay. Here. Say: dispatch, this is Robbery 7 checking in, I gotta go 10-2 real bad.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I gotta go 10-2 real bad. Wait, what's 10-2?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up outside their intermediate destination. A TH DAY BANK.

dialogues.speaker: AHHH
dialogues.text: aH  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy)

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: You want to come in with me or wait in the car?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Come in. 22a.  35 36 Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 23.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Okay. Lock the doors. We’ll be back in a second. And write yourself a note to your teacher, we’re gonna be a little late. He gets out, leaving the keys so Abbie can listen to the radio. He unfolds an umbrella and runs towards the bank, ignoring the CHEVY STATION WAGON that is parked innocuous across the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FORREST, TEDDY and WALLER sit in that chevy. Waller is in front seat of that car, alongside Teddy. Forrest is in th back seat. Forrest applies a layer of CLEAR NAIL POLISH to his fingertips. He’s got a new fake mustache on. Waller is wearing one too. He's whispering a little prayer to himse and makes the sign of the cross. Forrest looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the bank, there is only one teller (HELEN) working behind the glass, and a bit of a line, due to the older w counting out pennies at the counter.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN THE TELLER
dialogues.text: Yep, don’t worry, I’m keeping track... John Hunt stands at the little table with DEPOSIT SLIPS a begins to fill out a WITHDRAWAL FORM.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: But it’s your choice, right? You have to choose?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: So pick whatever you want. You liked baseball, right?  Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 23a.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Yeah.  37 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 24,

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: So pick baseball if you want to. Pick whatever you want - you just have to make sure you actually like it. (beat) Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Do you like your job?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Of course I do. I love it. As he’s talking, THE BANK DOORS OPEN AGAIN. Forrest and Waller enter. Forrest is carrying a briefcase Waller goes straight to the deposit slip island. Forrest makes a beeline straight for the MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. I’m looking for the manager...

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Well, that’d be me. What can I do for you this morning?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask about a business loan.

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Well sure, I bet we can help you with that. What sort of business are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: This kind. He flashes his GUN. Just enough for the manager to see it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into the manager's office, which has a big wind looking out into the rest of the bank. Forrest takes the liberty of closing the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Go ahead, sit down.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 24a. Mr. Owens does so, and then takes a seat behind his desk. Forrest sits down opposite him, setting his briefcase dow the desk. FORREST (CONT’D) How're you feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Not so great, since you're asking.  38 39 40 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 25.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Well, day’s still young. Mr. Owens sighs and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the glass doors of the office, Forrest and Mr. Ow can be seen chatting. At one point, Forrest nods in the direction of the bank lobby, and Mr. Owens looks nervousl that direction. Meanwhile, John Hunt and Tyler are still in line for the teller. He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you go up to the front there and ask what’s taking so long...

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: No! INT./EXT. JOHN HUNT’S POLICE CAR - CONTINUOUS 39 Abilene sits in the car, shuffling through songs on the r stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Owens leaves the office. Forrest follows him, and loi outside his door. Mr. Owens heads behind the counter. Waller watches, where Mr. Owens is filling the briefcase. ECU: Mr. Owens presses a SILENT ALARM BUTTON under the counter. Almost as if in response, Forrest TOUCHES his hearing aid He looks out the window, and then back at the counter... .++as Mr. Owens reappears, the briefcase hanging heavy fr his hand. ECU: the briefcase changes hands.  41 42 43 Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 26.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Thank you kindly. INT./EXT. JOHN HUNT’S POLICE CAR - CONTINUOUS 41 As Abilene kicks back, nodding her head to the pop tune that’s still playing, she notices the bank door opening i the rearview mirror. Is it her dad? No sir. Just two old men, leaving the bank and heading to car across the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt finally makes it up to the window, only to be interrupted by -

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen... John turns. He looks over his shoulder, just in time to s the Mr. Owens LOCKING THE DOORS FROM THE INSIDE. He raise his arms and calls out. MR. OWENS (CONT’D) (calling out) Excuse me ladies and gentlemen...please remain calm. It is my duty to inform you that this bank has just been robbed. There’s an IMMEDIATE UPROAR from the customers and other employees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the car, which is now in motion, as Teddy PEELS A from the bank. The rain still coming down hard. Forrest glances at the rearview mirror, making sure they’re not b tailed. Then he reaches up to his lip with his free hand PEELS THE MUSTACHE from his face.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You were pushin’ it...

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Nah, we got plenty of time. He can hear SIRENS in the distance.  44 45 46 47 Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minor chaos. The manager is trying to keep everyone calm. John Hunt in particular.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: - but my daughter is out there and -

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Sir, please, the police will be here momentarily —

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: For Christ’s sake! Have you not heard a single goddamn word I've said? I am the police! I will help you out if you can just unlock that door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door has been unlocked, and John is rushing out through the crowd of approaching PATROL OFFICERS to his c He knocks on the window. Abbie looks up and unlocks the d Another detective, OFFERMAN, recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: John? What the hell are you doing here? Hunt just shakes his head. Exasperated, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hot car pulls into a half-full parking lot on the edg town. Each of the three men quickly climbs out. Waller th the keys in the gutter. They all walk to their own cars. Forrest throws the suitcase in the trunk, and then casual climbs into the front seat, starts the engine. His car BACKFIRES as he departs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Abilene are in the bank now, sitting on chairs outside the offices while his father joins Offerman and L Kelley in interviewing the bank manager.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 28. Behind them, uniformed PATROL OFFICERS interview the bank witnesses one at a time. CAMERA HOLDS ON THEM as they watch the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: How old exactly?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: I'd say he was about fifty or sixty.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: More like sixty?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: or fifty?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Yeah, fifty or sixty.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: I think he had on a -

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: oh, I’m sorry sir. Is this your case? I thought you were a witness. The other cops chuckle. Hunt shakes his head... ...and while doing so, notices through the office window MAUREEN has arrived to pick up the kids. She spots him an gives him one of those looks.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And he was armed?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Yes, he had a gun.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: You saw it.

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean -

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: He pointed it at you?  48 49 50 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 29.

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: No. But he said he had one and I just -

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: You did what he said?

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: Because he said he had a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MR. OWENS
dialogues.text: And also - I mean, he was also sort of a gentleman. CAMERA PUSHES IN ON a police artist drawing a composite sketch of Forrest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+.who at this very moment is speeding down the highway, headed who knows where, high as a kite on the adrenaline that’s pumping through his veins. A grin on his face, win his hair. He ROLLS DOWN the dirty mud spattered window and lets the fresh air rush against his face. EXT. FORREST’S HOUSE - DAY 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest pulls into the driveway of HIS HOUSE - a modest little rental in East Dallas, across the street from a cemetery. INT. FORREST’S HOUSE - DAY 50 Teddy is dividing the loot. Waller is in the kitchen maki pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: You know how to make a perfect pancake?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: I’m asking you.  Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 29a. Moments later, Forrest is sitting at his table, bent over BEARCAT 100 police radio - a portable police scanner abou the size of a big walkie talkie. Wires creep out of the b of the radio, and run up to the pair of HEARING AIDES tha Forrest has been wearing. He’s working on this right now. Twisting the exposed copper, making sure it’s all firmly connected.  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 30.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It works out okay. She doesn’t speak a lick of English and I don’t know more than two words of Spanish, both of which I employ liberally, and we seem to get along just fine.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Ella ya es demasiado bueno para ti.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: What do I say to that, si?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Si. Absolutamente.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: I know you’re makin’ fun of me but you know what? I’m okay with that because I got a sense of humor about myself.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: I got a sense of humor about you too.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: She wants me to go to Buenos Aires with her. You ever been there?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: They got good poetry out of there.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You're thinking of Chile.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Same difference. What about St. Louis. You ever been to St. Louis?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Sure. I got arrested outside of McGurk’s there in 1962.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Well, McGurk and I both think it’s time you make your triumphant return. Forrest looks up now.  Buff Rev. (5/8/17)

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What's this got to do with you eloping?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Nothing. This has to do with us. I was talking to Yurkow the other day and then I did a little digging and I think I got a line on a pretty good score.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Gold.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Gold?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Gold. A whole mess of it, just sitting there in a safety deposit box in St. Louis.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do with gold?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Bury it in your backyard? You tell me, bud. why don’t you buy yourself a few beaded curtains for this dump. Forrest laughs. 30A.

dialogues.speaker: AHHH
dialogues.text: 51 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 31. (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he talks, CAMERA PUSHES IN on the TV, where the news i on... INT. JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - EVENING 51 Some miles away, John Hunt is watching the same news and eating leftover birthday cake.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: In local news today - bees! The Waxahachie Honey Festival is in full swing. We were there and we may have gotten a little sticky... Maureen sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Is it on the news?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Nah. It’s not big enough. No one cares.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: How big’s it have to be?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: For folks to care? Bigger’n fifteen hundred bucks. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 32.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Well, you care. (beat) Don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Only because they made as much in ten minutes as I make in a month and had a whole lot more fun doing it. I’m in the wrong line of work. I think I’m gonna quit.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: And do what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I'll figure something out. Go build houses with my dad. Do something useful. Maureen all but rolls her eyes. She’s heard this before.

dialogues.speaker: MAUREEN
dialogues.text: Okay. You can quit. (beat) Or...you can try and catch ‘em. He looks up at her, considering this. INT. FORREST’S HOUSE - EVENING 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest follows the guys to the door. Teddy bids Forrest farewell, and heads down to his car. Waller stops short of leaving.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: I’ve been meaning to ask you. You pick a house across from a cemetery on purpose?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: You really didn’t think about it?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: AHH OF
dialogues.text: aH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 32a.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Just wondering. I’1l see you next week. He takes off. Forrest stands in the doorway, watching as compatriots depart. INT. BEDROOM / FORREST’S HOUSE - EVENING 53 CRAAACCCKKKK. Forrest pull up the floorboards and begins deposit his latest hall in the crawlspace beneath. CAMERA PULLS BACK beneath the floorboards, revealing a significant stash of cash from previous plunderings, alon with various documents, fake IDs and a box of old Indian coins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits in that same little restaurant. Having anoth slice of pie and drawing in his notebook. The door chimes again. Someone enters. We don’t see who. Neither does Forrest, until she’s standing right in front his booth.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you’d ever actually call.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you’d pick up. So we're even. She sits down.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How's your truck?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: All fixed up. How about you? Been on the road I guess?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Selling a lot of bibles?  Eo Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 34.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: A whole lot. Top five salesman in the region, right here.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I don’t believe a word you say.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Probably a good idea. She looks more closely at him.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You're not wearing your hearing aide.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Your -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I can’t hear you. She laughs, catching on to the joke. The sound of POLICE RADIO kicks in, overtaking the audio he slides her his notebook, showing the picture he was drawing. It’s a drawing of a HORSE. The sound of the radio CONTINUES OVER...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ROBBERY MONTAGE Be 1. CAMERA SLOWLY PULLS BACK ON A WIDE TABLEAU SHOT, outsi BANK in DRIPPING SPRINGS, ARKANSAS. A car pulls right up right outside. 2. The pull back continues, only now we're outside a bank SPRINGFIELD, MISSOURI. A different car is pulled up in th same place. FORREST and Teddy get out.  56 57 Pink Rev. (3/24/17) 35. 3. Same shot, this time outside a bank in NORMAN, OKLAHOM with a third hot car outside. Forrest and Waller stroll o a bag of cash in Forrest’s hands. He climbs into his car steps on the gas. A big cloud of dust flies up as the car screeches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FILE slams down on John Hunt's desk. Offerman loudly proclaims:

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: Looks like John’s rainy day robber is at it again! There’s a gentle chorus of laughter as Hunt picks up the file.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah. Laugh it up. What is this? He examines the folder. Scans down, sees some text: OCTOB 2. NORMAN, OK. ARMED CAUCASIAN MALES. ELDERLY.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: Gene Dentler sent it over, said it made him think of you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Hilarious. Hunt flips to the composite sketch of the suspect...which looks remarkably similar to the one from his fateful encounter.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: But hey, don’t sweat it. I already got the AARP on the case. More laughter. But John looks closer at the file... INT. JOHN HUNT’S OFFICE / NORMAN SHERIFF'S DEPT. - DAY 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt is on the phone now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah, Gene, this is John Hunt. So what about this robbery?  58 Blue Rev. (3/10/17) 36. On the other end of the line, SHERIFF GENE DENTLER of the Norman PD kicks back at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DET. GENE DENTLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, the old guy! Yeah, same story. Small haul. No prints, no MO, no nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: So no leads?

dialogues.speaker: DET. GENE DENTLER
dialogues.text: Nope. Mainly on account of no one giving a shit. It’s just kind of a funny story.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah, armed robbery’s pretty damn funny.

dialogues.speaker: DET. GENE DENTLER
dialogues.text: I know. Oh, and speaking of funny here’s where it gets interesting. I told my wife about the whole deal and I guess she tells her sister because the next day her sister called me and told me about this thing she read in the paper that sounded real similar. Old fella with a gun...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Your wife’s sister, huh. Where's she live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John sits at a microfiche machine. MARTHA brings him a st of old slides.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: This enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Keep ‘em coming... John leans into the microfiche screen. The screen LIGHTS his face. He begins scanning over various newspaper headlines. ELDERLY BANDIT ROB CREDIT UNION. OLD MAN ROBBE PUZZLES POLICE. SENIOR STICKS UP GROCERY STORE. The text reflects on his face. He jots down DATES and LOCATIONS.  59 60 61 Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) Eve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt is on the phone again. Behind him, from one cut the next, Lt. Kelley is getting more interested in the ca

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Hey Marge, I’m calling about this xobbery you guys had on June 8th - is that case still open? AND AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am, could you fax over the report on that? AND AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What exactly do you mean when you say more than one? INT. LIVING ROOM - JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - NIGHT 60 John Hunt BURSTS THROUGH the front door, narrowly dodging kids, setting a BIG FILING BOX down on the kitchen table. He runs back out, and returns with a second box that he s down atop the first and begins to open it. Maureen, sitti at that table going over a textbook, eyes this stuff with bemusement. INT. LIVING ROOM - JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - NIGHT 61 John Hunt leans over a giant CORKBOARD laid out on his li room floor. Multiple state maps are pinned to it, representing a general layout of the Southwest. Abilene and Tyler Hunt are helping their daddy poke RED PUSHPINS into various points on the map. John has a stack police files that he’s going through, pulling city names each one.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: Seventy eight...seventy nine...eighty. John Hunt takes a sip from a beer bottle as Abbie sinks a into the spot on the map.  Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 37A.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: (to Tyler) Eighty. What’s after eighty?  62 Yellow Rev. (4/4/17)

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah you do.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE,
dialogues.text: Eighty-one.

dialogues.speaker: TYLER
dialogues.text: Eighty-one.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Eight-one. Barstow, Arizona. Barstow. Barstowwwwwwww. Tyler sinks the pin in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There we go. See, we're make a trail. It'll lead us right back to...

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: The bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah. The bad guy. And the bad guy came from... CAMERA zeroes in on CALIFORNIA...

62 Hunt and Lt. Kelley are presenting their case to the CAPT Offerman is in the office too. They are attempting to dramatically flip a blackboard around, but it gets stuck. and Kelly finally manage to get it turned around. Offerma rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLY
dialogues.text: There. Five states, 93 robberies, two years.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CALDER
dialogues.text: And you think it’s all the same guys?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yes we do.  Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 38a.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: So how do the same three guys. Get away. With all that?  Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 39.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Good question. Gonna bring your mom in later, figure maybe she can tell us.

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: My mom’s dead, dumbass.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: OFFERMAN
dialogues.text: Since last year.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: Shoot. Guess it’s up to us then.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: You wanna know how they get away with it? You remember my dad?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CALDER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Imagine him robbing a bank. The Captain laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's how they get away with it.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CALDER
dialogues.text: So what do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: What do we want to do?

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CALDER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Well, we're gonna catch him.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: We're gonna catch him. 63 INT. FORREST’S CAR / EXT. JEWEL’S HOUSE - DAY 63 Forrest is driving. He pulls off a country road and drives up a long driveway  64 Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 39A. Up ahead, at the end of the driveway, is a big COUNTRY HO presiding over a magnificent plot of land. Adjacent to th the house are stables and a small barn. EXT. JEWEL’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 64 He gets out of the car and walks up to the house. A DOG n INDY runs out to greet him. Followed by Jewel.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I thought I took a wrong turn.  65 66 Pink Rev. (3/24/17) 40.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Nope. This is me. * INT. JEWEL’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel shows him her house. It’s big, cozy, full of projec in-progress. The wall by the staircase is mostly stripped wallpaper, and on the plaster is a big cursive signature pencil.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: It looks terrible right now because I started stripping the paper off thinking I would change it - and then I found this on the plaster and now I’m afraid to cover it back * up. This is the man who built this * house. I looked it up and that was his name. He signed his name almost * 100 years ago and it’s still there. * They get to the kitchen, where there’s a big table with a bunch of soap-making stuff on it. JEWEL (CONT’D) That's where I’m making soap.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: You make soap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jewel and Forrest are in the stables with her three horse Clementine, Wiley and Dorothy Jean. Forrest is focusing o Dorothy Jean. She keeps nudging Forrest's hand. She likes attention.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: I've had Wiley here since he was born. And Clementine we bought from our neighbors, and I fell in love with her right away... Forrest bends down to scrape some mud off his shoe with a stick, and then stands upright and looks over the horizon Jewel's land stretches out as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: This all belongs to you, huh?  67 Pink Rev. (3/24/17)

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. My kids keep telling me to sell it but...I love it. They say it’s too expensive or that...I can’t handle it on my own. I say come out and give me a hand, then. I’m not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him for a moment, pausing before voicing a concern:

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're not married are you?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No. I was once. But we were real young.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Did you have any kids?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I hope not. EXT. JEWEL’S HOUSE - DAY Forrest and Jewel are siting on the front porch. Drinking whiskey and watching the wind blow through the trees. Ind sits at Jewel’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Do you miss him?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Sure. But...we were married when we were nineteen. And then the kids came and...you lose track of yourself sometimes. Or at least I do. And it’s so easy to just assume everything is fine, that this is fine, this is the way things are supposed to be. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AHHH
dialogues.text: Blue Rev. (3/10/17)

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You spend so much time thinking you're happy and then you wake up one morning and realize that, oh, maybe you aren't. Maybe you never were in the first place. Maybe you don’t even know what that means. And then something happens, like you lose someone, or even just your kids grow and move out, and then it’s what do you have left, you know? So yes, I miss him and there’s a part of me that always will but...I think..now it’s okay for me to be selfish. Because you think about - like ten years from now, where will you be, what'll you be doing, you know? There was a time where ten years, it was a lot, but now...now whenever I close a door I wonder: was that the last time I'll have a chance to do whatever that thing was? Another long silence.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: You know what I do when those doors close?

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I climb out the window. She laughs. FORREST (CONT’D) And if I ever get worried and where I'm going, I think of myself as a little boy. This tall. I think: would he be proud of me? And if the answer is no, well - then, well, I better walk on through. But if the answer is yes - that’s when you're exactly where you're supposed to be.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Is he proud of you? That little boy?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: He’s getting closer every day. 42.  68 69 70 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 43. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: But - you're never exactly where you're supposed to be, right? Because if you are, you're finished. Done. And ten-year-old you might have hopes and dreams but he doesn’t understand time...or the world...not the way you do. So you've just gotta keep pushing...trying new things... Forrest considers this. INT. FORREST’S HOUSE - DAY 68 Forrest is watching two FURNITURE DELIVERY MEN bring a br new BED into his house. There is other furniture there no too. Quick shots of a new couch, a new table... INT. BEDROOM - FORREST’S HOUSE - NIGHT 69 Forrest sits on his new bed. Feeling its softness. Nicest thing he’s ever bought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest sits at a bar next to Waller, who is regaling him with a TALL TALE of ill-doings.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: My Dad left when I was a kid and so when I was a teenager my Mom got remarried to well a ....cop, Christ. By then I was doing petty crimes...and well, the first thing he did was change all the locks and he wrote a like 10 page “new Manifesto” for our family..with lots of rules to follow. So it was Christmas and I had been out stealing cigarettes out of parked cars that type of thing..and came home late to find the house locked up like a federal prison. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AHHH EA HEHE HEHE
dialogues.text: Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 43a.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was a little drunk so I had to come thru a high window and the Christmas tree was blocking my entrance..so I am squeezing thru the window and balancing my self using the tree as a crutch and the decorations are clanging and falling and then I hear FREEZE! FREEZE! ...and I look thru the tinsel and there is my stepfather in full uniform, in combat position, both hands on his service revolver, ready to squeeze one off and well it was not a great way to begin and things only got worse from there...and so that is why I hate Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You want to get away with something big, though...you wait until the holidays. Everyone’s a little more forgiving, a little more generous...a little more ready to look the other way.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Tell me something.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Tell me more about St. Louis. Waller chuckles and downs his shot.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Buy me another drink and 1/11 tell you all about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 72 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 44. INT. FORREST’S CAR / HIGHWAY - DAWN 1 Now Forrest is asleep in his car. Blanket pulled up over shoulders, hat pulled over the brim of his eyes. An EIGHTEEN WHEELER roars by out his window. He sits up. Pulls out a watch. The source of that ticking. Looks at i It's cold an quiet and lonely, but somehow cozy at the sa time. He climbs into the front seat. Starts the engine. Steps o the gas. The engine BACKFIRES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has come up now. Forrest sits in a booth at some downtown breakfast joint. A waitress named MARLA with a r of-sunshine face fills his cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MARLA THE WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Late night or early morning?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Little bit of both. She winks at him. Forrest holds the coffee, letting it warm his hands. The door chimes. Teddy and Waller enter. They sit down opposite Forrest.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: (to waitress) Ma’am? Ma’am. Two more coffees please.  73 74 15 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 45.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: How was the drive?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: They keep getting longer. *

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: He didn’t like my book on tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG LENS ON: Forrest stands, alone, cut out against the He’s on a rooftop, looking down at the street below. LONG ZOOM OUT, until Forrest is just a tiny dot on the horizontal edge of a rooftop, backed up against the morni sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we’re with Forrest, and we see what he’s looking at. a BANK. A big one, big downtown branch in an old stone * building that looks like it could withstand an army. Teddy is up there. So is Waller. *

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: It's big. *

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Real big. * Teddy has a camera with a long lens. He snaps a few pictu Forrest sees an ARMORED TRUCK pull up in front of the ban He looks at his watch, takes note of the time, and then j it down in his little notebook. He watches as TWO GUARDS get out of the back of the truck head into the bank with an empty hand truck. Something ab that strikes his interest. Waller and Teddy see it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest and Teddy are casing the bank on the inside now. Waller is there too. It’s big and imposing, with high ceilings and marble columns. Footsteps echo everywhere. I feels more like Grand Central Station than a bank. *  Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 45a. Forrest stands at the deposit slip island, pretending to out a slip, writing notes instead. His gaze passes to Teddy...  16 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 46. .+.then to Waller...and then to the SECURITY CAMERAS. Then he walks up to the counter, quietly COUNTING HIS STE as he goes. One...two...three..four

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teller named ANGELA is waiting. He gives her a personal check.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Can I cash this check here?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA THE TELLER
dialogues.text: Certainly. Will that be all?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. Thank you. She turns to her register. To his left, Forrest can see the VAULT... ...just as the BRINKS GUARDS walk out. He pays close attention to them. To their uniforms, to the way they wal to the path they take, to the HAND TRUCK laden with black bags of cash and the way they nod to the SECURITY GUARD o site as they PASS THROUGH... Then, as he follows them, his gaze falls upon a YOUNG COU talking to a bank employee in a little cubicle. It looks they’re buying a house. He can’t help but look at them. He watches them for a lon time. CAMERA ZOOMS IN. Before too long we can hear their conversation. They’re talking about THEIR FUTURE.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELA THE TELLER
dialogues.text: Sir? Sir? Here’s your cash. He turns back to Angela as she passes him his cash and receipt. INT. FORREST’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They circle the bank in Forrest’s car.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: I’m not sure yet. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They drive past the Brinks truck.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: What I wanna know is how much they got in those trucks. Forrest looks at the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three guys sit back in the motel room, drinking beers looking over Forrest's handdrawn map of the bank and down and BLUEPRINTS of the bank itself. The TV is on in the corner. There’s some old movie playing, some late-night Western.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You really think we can do it?

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: We could probably do it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: We could probably do anything we set our minds to. I’m just saying: it sounds like we’re showing off.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Okay! Hell! Let's show off then. We been doing the same score, over and over and over. My bones are starting to hurt, man. I’m sixty seven years old. I gotta start thinking about my future.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: What do you think, Forrest? You think we can pull it off?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Probably. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Probably. Probably. You forget all about Paterson? Probably didn’t get you too far then.  78 79 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 48.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Difference between now and then is now - now I know what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: I know too. But I also know what I'm capable of. And these days... those are two different things.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll lay low after this.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: You. Laying low. That’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s why everyone's laughing. Forrest does laugh.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I'll think about it. He steps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door behind him and walks down the second st walkway to his own room. It’s all the way down on the oth side of the building, making for a long, leisurely walk. Down in the parking lot he sees man and woman arguing nea truck. They look like they just came from a heavy metal s He unlocks the door to his room. INT. FORREST’S SHITTY MOTEL ROOM - CONTINUOUS 79 He enters the room. He switches on the TV. That same movi on. He switches through channels until he lands on the NE Weather report. He takes off his jacket and hangs it in the closet. Something on the NEWS catches his attention.  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 4ea.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: We go now to Dallas, Texas, where police from multiple states have traced a string of dozens of bank robberies across multiple states to a band of highly skilled robbers. Making this crime spree even more unprecedented? These suspects a little bit older than your average criminal.  Yellow Rev. (4/4/17) 49. Forrest moves to the edge of the bed so as to see the TV better... ECU on TV: John Hunt and Lt. Kelley are being interviewed

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've got them figured somewhere between sixty and seventy years old. We call ‘em the Over-The- Hill Gang.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Good name.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Thanks. I came up with it. The camera shows a group of detectives all gathered toget in a conference room, reviewing case files. A COMPOSITE SKETCH is shown on screen - a strikingly accurate representation of Forrest Tucker.  Pink Rev. (3/24/17) 50.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: What you see here is we brought in detectives from just about every county in the area and some from as far away as Albuquerque and Little Rock. We've got some gentlemen from the FBI here too. We’re all just putting our heads together, comparing notes, stacking up clues...seeing if we can’t work together to nab these guys.

dialogues.speaker: LT. KELLEY
dialogues.text: We all grew up playing cops and robbers. Now we come into the office, go out on the streets, sometimes it feels like we’re doing the same thing. It’s all fun and games until they stick a gun in someone’s face and then you remember - we’ve got a job to do.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Now, old men, robbing banks - it seems like they would be fairly conspicuous. Any idea on how have they gotten away with it for so long?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Well frankly - these guys have way more experience robbing banks than we do catching them. But I think we’re getting up to speed.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Think you'll be the one to catch them?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: I’m sure any one of these folks here would be happy to do the job, but sure - I won’t lie. I’d love to finish the job and slap the cuffs on them myself. I hope that happens. I hope I have that chance.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Here’s hoping time doesn’t catch up with them before you do.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Detectives.

dialogues.speaker: AHHH
dialogues.text: ae

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Thank you. CAMERA PUSHES IN on John Hunt’s pixely image on that TV.. ...and then a MATCHING PUSH-IN ON FORREST, who’s staring at Hunt with fire in his eyes. He sits there for a while. Then he rises. He grabs his jacket and puts it back on. He walks out of his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks back down the long walkway. The couple he noticed earlier have made up and are making against the back bumper of the truck. He makes it to Teddy's room and knocks. The door opens. It's Teddy.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Back already?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yep. I thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: And? On the TV, a bunch of cowboys UNLOAD THEIR PISTOLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s early morning.  83 84 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) Gil Chilly MIST billowing through the air, obscuring everythi Waller walks down the street. He's looking for a new car. He tries the handle on one, but it’s locked. He finds another. Looks good. Isn’t locked. He gets in the car. Shuts the door. The sounds of the out world fall away. The car windows are misted over. Waller pries open the steering column with a screwdriver. Quickly, delicately, he HOTWIRES the car, striking the ignition wires together. As the car starts up, the STEREO KICKS ON, blaring something loud and jarring. He quickly turns it off. Now the only sound is the car, purring smoo and strong. INT. JOHN HUNT’S HOUSE - MORNING 83

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt and Maureen are in bed, giggling, making out. E morning. The BEEPER on the bedside table goes off. John grabs it, looks at it, and then sets it aside. A moment later, the PHONE by the bed rings. They both groan. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Hey, what’s up... Suddenly he bolts upright.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That big bank is a crime scene now. Lots of people talkin taking pictures. John Hunt walks from the outside in, following a ST. LOUIS DETECTIVE (DET. WAINWRIGHT).  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 51a.

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: You can see it on the tapes. They just sweep right in, lock step behind the guards, just escorting them to the vaults. Half the people here didn’t even know it was happening until...well... There is broken glass on the floor, a trail of MONEY, whi distracts Hunt. Detective Wainwright pauses, notices he’s distracted...

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Detective Hunt?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: This way. Another cop says:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER TIM
dialogues.text: Who's this - is this John Hunt?

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER TIM
dialogues.text: You're the talk of the town this morning, Detective. They pass a SECURITY GUARD (CLAYTON) who is being intervi by a police officer (OFFICER WALSH)...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER WALSH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to make you go over this so many times, but - first you followed them into the street -

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER WALSH
dialogues.text: - and that’s when you fired?  85 86 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 52.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD CLAYTON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like I said. Two times...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER WALSH
dialogues.text: And they fired back?

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD CLAYTON
dialogues.text: No sir, no they did not. They just drove away as fast as they could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teddy, Waller and Forrest are all crammed in the bathroom Teddy's shirt is hiked up above his waist. There’s a BLOO HOLE in his side, which Waller is in the process of stitc up. Forrest is holding a little bottle of whiskey over th wound.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Ready? Ready? Forrest pours alcohol over the wound and then Waller pres gauze to improvised sutures. Teddy breathes through the pain.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: Took off one of my love handles.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Eh, you still got plenty to work with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt makes it to the VAULT. It’s clearly been plunde

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Gold.

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: Gold.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: What are they gonna do with gold?

dialogues.speaker: DET. WAINWRIGHT
dialogues.text: You tell me. They’d have gotten away with it, too, if one of ‘em hadn't stopped to leave this. The detective points t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : a plastic evidence baggie.  Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 52A. In it is a 100 DOLLAR BILL. Hunt looks at it. Written at the top of the bill in small print are the wor  87 88 89 Goldenrod Rev. (4/30/17) 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest Tucker’s CUTLASS cuts across a long beautiful str of country road. INT. FORREST’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 88 Forrest listens to the NEWS on the radio as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO NEWS
dialogues.text: ...the three men entered the vault dressed as armored truck drivers. Reports put the amount stolen in excess of three hundred thousand dollars. One of the perpetrators is believed to have been injured when a security guard fired on - He shuts it off and looks to the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+-where TEDDY is laying, hand on his side.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: How you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: I’m all right. (beat) We almost did it, didn’t we?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: We did do it. CAMERA TRACKS INTO THE TRUNK, where a HUGE DUFFLE BAG sit alongside Forrest's classic briefcase... INT. FORREST’S HOUSE - DAY 89

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest, Waller and Forrest sit in Forrest’s house. They' looking at the contents of that bag. A warm glow reflects their faces.  90 91 92 93 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54.

dialogues.speaker: WALLER
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: That’s that, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: That’s that. INT. FORREST’S HOUSE - DAY 90 Waller helps Teddy to his car. Teddy looks back to Forres one last time before he shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Teddy... Teddy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY GREEN
dialogues.text: I’1l see you on the next one. Teddy and Waller get in their car. Forrest watches them drive off. INT. WALLER’S CAR - DAY 91 Waller drives. Teddy sits in the passenger seat, sitting back, resting. Waller glances at him, and then turns his eyes back to th road. CAMERA follows his gaze and turns to the road too. Stretc on in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful day in the country. Green hills, gentle wind. Forest stands at a fence on the edge of Jewel's property, wind rustling his hair as he leans against the slats, loo out to the land.  94 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54a. Jewel is riding out and back again. A silhouette on the horizon, coming into focus. She’s a natural rider, knows she's doing. Finally she returns to the fence, sidling up to Forrest a looking down at him from above. Her cheeks are flushed an she’s smiling broadly. In her element.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want to try?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: Are you scared? I thought this was on your list.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: oh, still is. She laughs, and heads out again. Hooves thundering, then diminishing. He watches her go. Admiring her. A little bi enchanted. INT. DINING ROOM - JEWEL’S HOUSE - DAY 94 Jewel is outside the house, taking her muddy boots off - Forrest can see her through the windows. He steals a peek at her open mail on the kitchen table. He sees a bill from the bank. He can’t make heads or tail it - has never seen a mortgage payment in his life - but takes note of the bank name: TEXAS LOAN & COMMERCE. And below that stack of mail he sees the morning’s NEWSPA with the headline: COPS CLOSE IN ON OVER-THE-HILL GANG. He picks it up to get a closer look. There’s a picture of John Hunt there, posing with Lt. Kel and other detectives. Jewel returns. Forrest fold the paper over and sets it do

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What’d you find?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Just catching up on the news. He’s not sure if she’s seen that article or not.  95 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54B.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: What's going on with the world?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Still turning. She doesn’t mention the article. He doesn’t mention it an further, but he does look down and see John Hunt’s pictur one more time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Hunt sits in an office, opposite three FBI Agents - AGENT MORTON and AGENT RICK.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT MORTON
dialogues.text: You know the bureau was actually put together to catch guys like these?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT RICK
dialogues.text: One man war. There was Dillinger - who else?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT MORTON
dialogues.text: Dillinger and a bunch of other guys like ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT RICK
dialogues.text: The point is: you’ve done your part, John. You did a good job.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT RICK
dialogues.text: Hard part’s over. Now it’s the part where we bring this home.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: Or this is the part where I remember one little clue - one little piece that makes the whole thing click into place and you say, thank you John. You cracked the case. You caught the bad guy. That's good work.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT MORTON
dialogues.text: You remember something?  95a 96 97 98 Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54c.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN HUNT
dialogues.text: No. OMITTED 95a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest walks towards a bank. Striding right up to it, ey the prize. The usual routine it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest enters the bank. He looks around. He finds the manager (MRS. PHILIPS). Still his usual rout

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Are you the manager?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they sit in a cubicle on the office floor. Turns out not the same routine after all. Forrest actually seems nervous. He keeps shifting in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: You want to take over the mortgage?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I just want to pay for it all up front.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: Well, that could certainly be done, but she would need to come in and sign over the -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No, I want to do it like a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: I see.  Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54D.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: I just want to give you some money and she’d never know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a heck of a Christmas present. So you have a few options. One is you could make a gift to her. The other is she could sign the property over to you and -

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No, no. I don’t want to do that. I just want to pay for it all. I don’t want to trouble her with it or for her to know or...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: Well, she'll know one way or another.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: What if I have the money here right now?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: Right now?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: You have it?

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: No. But what if I did?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: She'd still need to come in and sign off on the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: It would be very easy. Just a bit of quick paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: But I can’t do it right now.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. PHILIPS
dialogues.text: No.  99

dialogues.speaker: 99A
dialogues.text: Buff Rev. (5/8/17) 54E.

dialogues.speaker: FORREST
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you. He gets up. As he leaves, the bank continues with its day day activities. We HOLD ON IT for an unreasonable amount time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest walks back out of the bank. First time in his lif he’s just walked out of a bank with nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LATER 99R
dialogues.text: Forrest and Jewel stand by a jewelry counter at a departm store.

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: What were you looking for today? She scans the glass display cases and their shimmering contents.

dialogues.speaker: JEWEL
dialogues.text: May I see that one?

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
